p: Climate change is expected to cause severe impacts on biodiversity including change in geographical range and local abundance [ 1– 3]. The magnitude of future climate change is a key predictor of species extinction risk and accelerated biodiversity loss [ 4], and when combined with habitat loss and fragmentation, pollution, introduction of exotic species and overexploitation—or the "evil-quartet" [ 5], represents one of the main conservation challenges of modern times [ 6]. Therefore, climate change is increasingly a part of the current biodiversity crisis, in which the observed extinction rates are much higher than expected from historical background rates [ 7, 8], with 22% of global vertebrates, including mammals, listed as threatened by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) Red List [ 9, 10].
